text: this project has been a personal dream
of mine since I came to the bog layin
and so today it's so exciting to have a
facility that has changed really
dramatically the dynamic between the
university itself and citizens Vox and
the people who come to the city the
Weston library is part of the body in
libraries a group of research libraries
in the University of auxin just founded
in 1602 and is now the home for the body
and special collections it's rare books
manuscripts archives the libraries are
actually a refurbishment of a much older
building designed by Giles Gilbert Scott
completed in the early years of the war
but by the end of the 20th century had
really fallen seriously into decline we
really needed to undertake a major
renovation of the building just to stop
it from burning down Charles Gilbert
Scott was a famous architect of his time
famous for instance for the the red
telephone boxes but he really turned
rather a blank face to Broad Street he
didn't live up to the extraordinary
setting here in right in the historic
center of Oxford and if you think across
the street there are the most beautiful
buildings hawks Moors Clarendon building
wrens Sheldonian the brief to us was to
turn the existing building into a
library for special collections with
public facilities exhibitions so the
overall number of books that are
actually in the building now it's much
less than what was there before but that
meant that we could carve out bigger
spaces for other uses so there's the
public space the exhibition spaces and
then we could create a new reading room
there's an amazing new
up on the top of the building love these
think fantastic news out over Oxford the
dreaming spires of Oxford underground we
have completely refurbished storage
spaces upstairs we have reading rooms
where scholars and members of the public
can come and consult materials we have
spaces where conservation of library
materials can take place new facilities
where and the latest technique can be
applied to the preservation of library
collections in a way externally this is
the biggest change by introducing this
long horizontal glass wall some three
meters or so back it's completely
transformed the facade of the building
to something that's much lighter than it
was we're standing inside the Western
Library in a space that used to be 11
stories of book shelving and is now our
space where we're able to share our
great collections with the general
public well when it came in and looked
up and what I really like was the fact
that instead of walls hiding the books
because after all it's a library the
fact that you've got glass means you
seal the books when I was a student here
people said that it was a bit depressing
it was a bit 30s a bit like a public
lavatory now it's got this very nice
canteen and the good exhibitions very
spacious and it really has made a
difference the centre of Oxford
previously I walked around it for many
many years and they always seemed to
exclude people now that it's open with
the Glastron it's very very welcoming
there's a joy
it's become one of the most loved
buildings in an incredibly short space
of time in this city full of
extraordinary buildings and that's been
one of the most wonderful aspects of the
whole project
